facts.text: Appellant was a Superintendent of Police in the service of the former Travancore State and retired sometime in 1940.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant who was a Superintendent of Police in the service of the former Travancore State, retired sometime in 1940.

facts.text: After retirement, appellant spent time studying Vedanta philosophy and expounding it to persons keen on understanding it.

anchor.surface_text: After retirement he was spending his time in studying Vedanta philosophy and expounding the same to such persons as were keen on understanding it.

facts.text: Appellant gathered a number of disciples, one of whom was J. Levy of London, U.K.

anchor.surface_text: He soon gathered about him a number of disciples, one of whom was J. Levy of London, U.K.

facts.text: Levy along with others received instructions in Vedanta from the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Levy along with others used to receive instructions in Vedanta from the appellant.

facts.text: Levy used to come to Travancore from England at regular intervals and stay there for a few months at a time to attend appellant's discourses on Vedanta.

anchor.surface_text: He used to companye to Travancore from England at regular intervals and stay there for a few months at a time and attend the discourses given by the appellant and so had the benefit of his teachings on Vedanta.

facts.text: Levy had an account in Lloyds Bank at Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: Levy had an account in Lloyds Bank at Bombay.

facts.text: On December 13, 1941, Levy transferred Rs. 2,41,103-11-3 from his account to an account opened in appellant's name in the same bank.

anchor.surface_text: On December 13, 1941, Levy transferred the entire balance standing to his credit in this account amounting to Rs. 2,41,103-11-3, to the credit of an account which he got the appellant to open in his name in the same bank.

facts.text: From time to time after 1941, Levy deposited further sums into appellant's Lloyds Bank account in Bombay, totaling about Rs. 4,50,000 up to August 19, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, from time to time Levy put in further sums into the appellants aforesaid account in Lloyds Bank, Bombay. It appears that the payments so made up to August 19, 1951, amounted to about Rs. 4,50,000/-

facts.text: Appellant transferred moneys from his Lloyds Bank account in Bombay to his account in a bank at Trivandrum in Travancore from time to time.

anchor.surface_text: From time to time the appellant got moneys transferred from his account at the Lloyds Bank, Bombay, to his account in a bank at Trivandrum in Travancore.

facts.text: Appeal arises out of income-tax assessments against appellant for assessment years 1122, 1123 and 1124 according to Malayalam era.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal arises out of orders for assessment to income- tax passed against the appellant for the assessment years 1122, 1123 and 1124, all according to the Malayalam era.

facts.text: Accounting periods for 1122, 1123, 1124 M.E. were August 17, 1945 to August 16, 1946; August 17, 1946 to August 16, 1947; August 17, 1947 to August 16, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The respective accounting periods according to the Gregorian calendar were from August 17, 1945, to August 16, 1946, August 17, 1946, to August 16, 1947, and August 17, 1947, to August 16, 1948.

facts.text: During the relevant periods, Levy deposited Rs. 13,304, Rs. 29,948 and Rs. 19,983 respectively into appellant's Lloyds Bank account in Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that during these periods Levy bad deposited in the appellants account at Lloyds Bank in Bombay the following respective sums Rs. 13,304/-, Rs. 29,948/- and Rs. 19,983/-

facts.text: During the same periods, appellant obtained transfers of Rs. 81,200, Rs. 47,000 and Rs. 37,251 from Bombay account to Trivandrum account.

anchor.surface_text: During the same periods the appellant had obtained transfers of the following respective sums from his Bombay account to his Trivandrum account Rs. 81,200/-, Rs. 47,000/- and Rs. 37,251/-

facts.text: Income-tax Officer, Trivandrum, assessed appellant to tax on the transferred amounts as foreign income brought into Travancore.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer, Trivandrum, assessed the appellant to tax on the latter amounts as foreign income, i.e., income arising in India, and brought into Travancore State in the relevant periods.

facts.text: Appellant appealed the assessment orders to Appellate Assistant Commissioner, who consolidated them and dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Tile appellant appealed from these assessment orders to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner who companysolidated them into one appeal. The Appellate Assistant Commissioner dismissed the appeal

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Appellate Tribunal, which dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: and companyfirmed the orders of the Income-tax Officer. The appellant then went up in appeal to the Appellate Tribunal but that appeal also failed.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal referred two questions to Travancore-Cochin High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereafter obtained an order from the Tribunal referring the following Questions to the High Court of Travancore-Cochin for decision Whether the aforesaid receipts from John H. Levy companystitute income taxable under the Travancore Income-tax Act, 1121 ?

facts.text: High Court answered first question affirmatively and second in favor of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the first question in the affirmative. It however answered the second question in favour of the appellant, holding that he was carrying on a vocation or occupation in that State

facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court by special leave from High Court judgment dated March 8, 1956 in I.T.R. No. 24 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 8, 1956, of the Travancore-Cochin High Court at Ernakulam in I.T.R. No. 24 of 1954.

facts.text: No evidence that appellant made it a condition to impart knowledge only to those prepared to pay.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberevidence to show, that the appellant had made it a companydition that he would impart such knowledge only to those who were prepared to pay for it.

facts.text: Appellant taught Vedanta without motive or intention of making profit.

anchor.surface_text: We have therefore to proceed on the basis that the appellant was teaching his, disciples Vedanta without any motive or, intention of making a profit out of such activity.

facts.text: Levy stated in affidavit that sums paid were gifts to mark esteem and affection, and he had benefit of appellant's teachings on Vedanta.

anchor.surface_text: He drew our attention to the affidavit of Levy where it is stated all sums of money paid into his account by me have been gifts to mark my esteem and affection for him and for numberother reason. But Levy also there said, I have had the benefit of his teachings on Vedanta

arguments.claim: Appellant was carrying on a vocation of teaching Vedanta

arguments.claim: Profit motive irrelevant to determine if activity is vocation; taxable if produces income

anchor.surface_text: Again, it is well-established that it is not the motive of the person doing an act which decides whether the act done by him is the carrying on of a business, profession or vocation. If any business, profession or vocation in fact produces an income, that is taxable income

arguments.claim: Voluntary payments taxable if made by virtue of office or vocation, from donee's perspective

anchor.surface_text: These cases illustrate the application of the well-settled principle that in the case of a voluntary payment, no tax can be levied on it if it had been made for reasons purely personal to the donee and unconnected with his office or vocation while it will be taxable if it was made because of the office or vocation of the donee.

arguments.claim: Payments are remuneration, not personal gift; test per Reed v Seymour

anchor.surface_text: It is well established that in cases of this kind the real question is, as Rowlatt J. put it in Reed v. Seymour , But is it in the nature of a personal gift or is it a remuneration?, an observation which was quoted with approval by Viscount Cave, L. C.

arguments.claim: Teaching was causa causans of the payments

anchor.surface_text: We have no doubt in this case that the imparting of the teaching was the causa causans of the making of the gift it was not merely a causa sine qua non.

arguments.claim: No exemption under s.4(3)(vii) as payments arise from exercise of vocation

anchor.surface_text: In the view that we take, namely, that the payments with which we are concerned, were income, arising from the vocation of the appellants a teacher of Vedanta, no question of exemption under s. 4(3)(vii) of the Act arises.

holdings.text: The teaching of Vedanta by the appellant can properly be called the carrying on of a vocation.

anchor.surface_text: We think therefore that the teaching of Vedanta by the appellant in this case can properly be called the carrying on of a vocation by him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Teaching is inherently a vocation; Vedanta teaching qualifies; activity systematic with disciples and regular instruction; profit motive irrelevant per established precedents like Commissioner of Inland Revenue v. Incorporated Council of Law Reporting.

holdings.text: The payments made by Levy were income received by the appellant from his vocation of teaching Vedanta.

holdings.text: No question of exemption under s. 4(3)(vii) of the Act arises.

anchor.surface_text: In the view that we take, namely, that the payments with which we are concerned, were income, arising from the vocation of the appellants a teacher of Vedanta, no question of exemption under s. 4(3)(vii) of the Act arises.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Payments arise from exercise of vocation, so exemption condition not satisfied.
